intro: Phacelia cryptantha var. derivata, commonly known as the Sierra phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its blue to violet flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats such as slopes and meadows. It has small, lance-shaped leaves and produces numerous small, showy flowers that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies. This variety is known for its ecological importance in supporting local wildlife and its role in stabilizing soil in arid environments.
